description: A military conflict fought between the Dzungar Khanate and the Qing dynasty for control over Tibet.

historical_context.Ganden_Phodrang: Regime established by the 5th Dalai Lama with the support of Güshi Khan, founder of the Khoshut Khanate.
historical_context.Tsewang_Rabtan_invasion: Tsewang Rabtan of the Dzungar Khanate invaded Tibet in 1717, deposing and killing Lha-bzang Khan, the last ruler of the Khoshut Khanate.

belligerents.Qing_dynasty: Led by the Kangxi Emperor, with support from Polhané Sönam Topgyé of Tsang and Kangchennas of Western Tibet

Qing_dynasty.Yue_Zhongqi: Han Chinese General who conquered Tibet for the Qing
Qing_dynasty.Jalangga: Manchu Bannermen, succeeded Yue Zhongqi as commander in 1732

military_campaigns.Qing_response_1718: A Qing army was sent to clear traditional trade routes but was defeated by the Dzungars at the Battle of the Salween River.
military_campaigns.Qing_expulsion_1720: A Qing expedition expelled the Dzungars from Tibet in 1720, beginning Qing rule of Tibet.

post_war_situation.Qing_rule_of_Tibet: Lasted until the fall of the Qing dynasty in 1912.
post_war_situation.Dzungar_succession: Tsewang Rabtan was succeeded by Tsewang Rabtan as Khan of the Dzungars.

cultural_and_political_impact.Qing_manipulation: The Manchu Kangxi emperor incited anti-Muslim sentiment to gain support against the Dzungar leader Galdan, spreading false claims about Galdan's religious affiliations and intentions.
